title: 109_s2007
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Commission on Health Care Act". Congress finds that Americans are expected to spend $1.9 trillion on healthcare in 2005, up from $1.4 trillion in 2001. Rising healthcare costs jeopardize coverage for 174 million Americans with employer-sponsored insurance. Approximately 46 million people lacked health insurance in 2004, and the number of uninsured individuals is expected to grow. Medicare provided insurance to 41.7 million elderly and disabled Americans in 2004. In 2004, the Medicaid program provided healthcare for 55 million low-income individuals, costing approximately $606 billion in federal and state expenditures. The purpose of the Medicaid program is outlined in Section 3. The National Commission on Health Care is established to examine and report on rising health care costs, barriers to adequate coverage, and issues faced by individuals in public health care programs. It will evaluate evidence from relevant government agencies on these matters. The National Commission on Health Care will review past investigations, including those by executive branch, congressional, and independent commissions, as well as State and local entities with innovative solutions. It will investigate and report to the President and Congress on policy solutions for health care problems, including the lack of insurance for nearly 46 million Americans. The National Commission on Health Care is established in the legislative branch and will review past investigations to report policy solutions for health care problems to the President and Congress. The National Commission on Health Care is composed of 10 members appointed by various leaders from both the Democratic and Republican parties. The National Commission on Health Care consists of 10 members appointed by leaders from both the Democratic and Republican parties. Members must have diverse political affiliations, cannot be government officials, and should be prominent US citizens with relevant experience. The National Commission on Health Care consists of 10 members appointed by leaders from both parties with diverse political affiliations. Members must have relevant experience in health care administration, business, public administration, or research institutions. The deadline for appointment is October 15, 2005, or 60 days after the enactment of the Act. The Commission will meet after all members are appointed, with six members constituting a quorum. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The National Commission on Health Care consists of 10 members appointed by leaders from both parties with diverse political affiliations. Members must have relevant experience in health care administration, business, public administration, or research institutions. The Commission will meet after all members are appointed, with six members constituting a quorum. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 6. FUNCTIONS OF COMMISSION. The National Commission on Health Care is tasked with conducting a study on various aspects of health care, including rising costs, impacts on businesses, provision by state and local agencies, and effects on insurance premiums. The National Commission on Health Care will review health care premiums for businesses and individuals, private health insurance industry, public health programs, necessary innovations for affordable care, congressional oversight, resource allocation, and relevant areas in the public and private sectors. Lessons learned from past legislative structuring of health care will also be evaluated. The National Commission on Health Care will review and analyze government policies and procedures related to administering health care. It will submit reports to the President and Congress with findings and recommendations, including proposals for organization and management arrangements. The National Commission on Health Care will have powers to review and analyze government policies related to health care administration. It will submit reports with findings and recommendations to the President and Congress. The National Commission on Health Care has the authority to conduct hearings, gather evidence, and enter into contracts to fulfill its duties under the Act. It is also authorized to obtain information from federal agencies for the purposes of the Act. The National Commission on Health Care can request information from federal agencies, and the General Services Administration must provide assistance to the Commission as required by law. Information received by the Commission must be handled and disseminated in accordance with relevant laws and regulations. General Services will provide administrative support and services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. Other departments and agencies of the United States can also offer assistance, funds, facilities, staff, and support services as authorized by law. The Commission is allowed to accept, use, and dispose of gifts or donations of services or property, and can use the United States mails in the same manner as other government agencies. SEC. 8. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Commission's chairperson, with input from the vice chairperson, can appoint and determine the compensation of staff members without following standard federal hiring procedures. The staff director and other necessary personnel can be appointed under these rules, with pay not exceeding that of an Executive Schedule level V position. Staff members are considered federal employees. The Commission's staff director and personnel are federal employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their regular employment rights. The Commission can also procure consultant services as needed. The Commission can procure consultant services from experts and consultants at rates not exceeding those of a person at level IV of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 9. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of the Commission may receive compensation at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule and travel expenses while performing duties. The Commission can submit interim and final reports to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting the final report, allowing for the conclusion of its activities. The Commission will conclude its activities by providing testimony to Congress and disseminating the final report. SEC. 11. FUNDING. Authorization of $6,000,000 for this Act. Funds available until Commission termination.
